Zip ties (two small ones end to end between the wires work just fine). Not pretty, not reusable, but cheap.

We used to use zip ties or electrical tape if it was needed, although it was not usually necessary as they tend to stay together pretty well. Now we use WAGO connectors and that holds the wires together quite well. Then they can be zip tied, taped, or put in a 3d printed bracket for more organization.

Luckily you can reuse the housings, just need to replace contacts.

I posted the price of the Anderson Connectors in my team‚Äôs discord server, this is what my mentor said:

bet it works better then 30 amp wires twisted together and wrapped around with tape

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-02-20T02:45:08.954Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":390,"readers_count":389,"score":113.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":455374,"topic_slug":"alternative-to-anderson-clips","display_username":"Rocky","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58611,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/alternative-to-anderson-clips/455374/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3313413,"name":"Brett B Bonner","username":"bbonner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bbonner/{size}/155176_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-20T04:01:19.016Z","cooked":"

A narrow zip tie will pass through the same holes you use for the clip. The little 4" ones we use for most wire bundling work great. We zip tie most PP connections, but keep a few of the clips around for use where they need to be more easily removed/replaced, or for larger built-up groups of PP connectors.

We tried 3D printing some clips last year but they were quite weak and easily broken, so they never made it onto a robot.

A similar kit (with 30 amp metal contacts instead of 45 amp) is 113$ at robobitz and it actually shipped faster to Texas despite being located in Canada than Andymark did.

Rocky_S:

bet it works better then 30 amp wires twisted together and wrapped around with tape

Idk man my starter motor power circuit involves a wire nut and that‚Äôs been chooching for like, 20 years now. Some waterproof tape would probably do nicely on top of that.

RoboBitz

Powerpole Set 1

PP30 Powerpole Connectors Set Package Contents: 100 Red Housings 100 Black Housings 200 Pins Product Information: Recommended for 10-12 AWG wire Dovetail Housing Design Available Individually or in Sets Looking for a way to mount them? Check out...

Price: CAD 149.99

Where are you pricing those from? Buying from powerwerx is about 40% cheaper than that.

Those really aren‚Äôt that expensive when you consider the costs of what goes on our robots.
Price what it would cost for wago 221s. Or what a spool of 100 feet of pure copper wire costs. Or one kraken motor, or one neo with speed controller.

Tom_Line:

Where are you pricing those from?

Their post with the price being referenced was a screenshot of AndyMark‚Äôs website.

Yikes.

Unless I‚Äôm missing something obvious, the housings are $0.48 a piece from powerwerx, and the metal connectors are $0.20. Much cheaper.

I‚Äôve never found a need to use the retaining clips as long as the contacts are properly inserted. However, I have bent 10 Gauge solid steel or copper wire to hold APP blocks together in lieu of roll pins; this should also work as a retaining clip.

I‚Äôll second the Powerwerx suggestion. We never buy the connectors from anyone else.

We 3D print our own clips.

We print these, we‚Äôve used them the past few years. Made some in PLA and some in ABS. Specifically the file PP_Clip_90. We break those little pins off in the middle because they‚Äôre pretty useless but these do a good job at holding connections together

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2024-02-20T17:48:25.412Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":96,"readers_count":95,"score":24.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":455374,"topic_slug":"alternative-to-anderson-clips","display_username":"Allison Conrad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35333/files","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Parametric PowerPole Clip by diodenschein - Thingiverse","clicks":2},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/4/b/4b6ffc764382261d281b416e5daa083c3e279993.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20690,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6421 Mentor // TWIST Program Director"},"post_url":"/t/alternative-to-anderson-clips/455374/17","custom_user_title":"6421 Mentor // TWIST Program Director","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3313782,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-20T17:51:09.605Z","cooked":"
scubadiv3r:

We break those little pins off in the middle

Their purpose in this design is to confirm that the connector is fully mated, not to provide strength.
(Edit: and they‚Äôre actually redundant, see below, I didn‚Äôt see the feature on the side at first)

We‚Äôve done zipties and the injection molded ones, and the zipties will probably win this year.

I should have clarified better, but we do it because they‚Äôre so thin they bust immediately when we try and put the connectors on so we don‚Äôt worry about it. The grooves on the sides only lock in correctly if it‚Äôs aligned correctly, so not a big deal
